relatedVulnerabilities.description: Included in Log4j 1.2 is a SocketServer class that is vulnerable to deserialization of untrusted data which can be exploited to remotely execute arbitrary code when combined with a deserialization gadget when listening to untrusted network traffic for log data. This affects Log4j versions up to 1.2 up to 1.2.17.

vulnerability.description: Deserialization of Untrusted Data in Log4j

relatedVulnerabilities.description: In Django 1.11.x before 1.11.18, 2.0.x before 2.0.10, and 2.1.x before 2.1.5, an Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Output Used by a Downstream Component issue exists in django.views.defaults.page_not_found(), leading to content spoofing (in a 404 error page) if a user fails to recognize that a crafted URL has malicious content.

Django 1.10 before 1.10.7, 1.9 before 1.9.13, and 1.8 before 1.8.18 relies on user input in some cases to redirect the user to an "on success" URL. The security check for these redirects (namely ``django.utils.http.is_safe_url()``) considered some numeric URLs "safe" when they shouldn't be, aka an open redirect vulnerability. Also, if a developer relies on ``is_safe_url()`` to provide safe redirect targets and puts such a URL into a link, they could suffer from an XSS attack.

vulnerability.description: Moderate severity vulnerability that affects django

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Django 1.11 before 1.11.29, 2.2 before 2.2.11, and 3.0 before 3.0.4 allows SQL Injection if untrusted data is used as a tolerance parameter in GIS functions and aggregates on Oracle. By passing a suitably crafted tolerance to GIS functions and aggregates on Oracle, it was possible to break escaping and inject malicious SQL.

A flaw was found in keycloak, where the default ECP binding flow allows other authentication flows to be bypassed. By exploiting this behavior, an attacker can bypass the MFA authentication by sending a SOAP request with an AuthnRequest and Authorization header with the user's credentials. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to confidentiality and integrity.

vulnerability.description: ECP SAML binding bypasses authentication flows

relatedVulnerabilities.description: By design, the JDBCAppender in Log4j 1.2.x accepts an SQL statement as a configuration parameter where the values to be inserted are converters from PatternLayout. The message converter, %m, is likely to always be included. This allows attackers to manipulate the SQL by entering crafted strings into input fields or headers of an application that are logged allowing unintended SQL queries to be executed. Note this issue only affects Log4j 1.x when specifically configured to use the JDBCAppender, which is not the default. Beginning in version 2.0-beta8, the JDBCAppender was re-introduced with proper support for parameterized SQL queries and further customization over the columns written to in logs. Apache Log4j 1.2 reached end of life in August 2015. Users should upgrade to Log4j 2 as it addresses numerous other issues from the previous versions.

Django before 2.2.24, 3.x before 3.1.12, and 3.2.x before 3.2.4 has a potential directory traversal via django.contrib.admindocs. Staff members could use the TemplateDetailView view to check the existence of arbitrary files. Additionally, if (and only if) the default admindocs templates have been customized by application developers to also show file contents, then not only the existence but also the file contents would have been exposed. In other words, there is directory traversal outside of the template root directories.
follow-redirects is vulnerable to Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor

vulnerability.description: Exposure of sensitive information in follow-redirects

relatedVulnerabilities.description: axios is vulnerable to Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity

vulnerability.description: axios Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity vulnerability

relatedVulnerabilities.description: CVE-2020-9493 identified a deserialization issue that was present in Apache Chainsaw. Prior to Chainsaw V2.0 Chainsaw was a component of Apache Log4j 1.2.x where the same issue exists.

vulnerability.description: Deserialization of Untrusted Data in Apache Log4j

relatedVulnerabilities.description: JMSAppender in Log4j 1.2 is vulnerable to deserialization of untrusted data when the attacker has write access to the Log4j configuration. The attacker can provide TopicBindingName and TopicConnectionFactoryBindingName configurations causing JMSAppender to perform JNDI requests that result in remote code execution in a similar fashion to CVE-2021-44228. Note this issue only affects Log4j 1.2 when specifically configured to use JMSAppender, which is not the default. Apache Log4j 1.2 reached end of life in August 2015. Users should upgrade to Log4j 2 as it addresses numerous other issues from the previous versions.

vulnerability.description: JMSAppender in Log4j 1.2 is vulnerable to deserialization of untrusted data

relatedVulnerabilities.description: A maliciously crafted URL to a Django (1.10 before 1.10.7, 1.9 before 1.9.13, and 1.8 before 1.8.18) site using the ``django.views.static.serve()`` view could redirect to any other domain, aka an open redirect vulnerability.

vulnerability.description: Moderate severity vulnerability that affects django

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Django 1.11 before 1.11.28, 2.2 before 2.2.10, and 3.0 before 3.0.3 allows SQL Injection if untrusted data is used as a StringAgg delimiter (e.g., in Django applications that offer downloads of data as a series of rows with a user-specified column delimiter). By passing a suitably crafted delimiter to a contrib.postgres.aggregates.StringAgg instance, it was possible to break escaping and inject malicious SQL.

A SQL Injection issue in the SQL Panel in Jazzband Django Debug Toolbar before 1.11.1, 2.x before 2.2.1, and 3.x before 3.2.1 allows attackers to execute SQL statements by changing the raw_sql input field of the SQL explain, analyze, or select form.
Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor in NPM follow-redirects prior to 1.14.8.

vulnerability.description: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor in follow-redirects

relatedVulnerabilities.description: In Django 2.2 before 2.2.25, 3.1 before 3.1.14, and 3.2 before 3.2.10, HTTP requests for URLs with trailing newlines could bypass upstream access control based on URL paths.

vulnerability.description: Potential bypass of an upstream access control based on URL paths in Django

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Django before 1.11.27, 2.x before 2.2.9, and 3.x before 3.0.1 allows account takeover. A suitably crafted email address (that is equal to an existing user's email address after case transformation of Unicode characters) would allow an attacker to be sent a password reset token for the matched user account. (One mitigation in the new releases is to send password reset tokens only to the registered user email address.)

vulnerability.description: Potential account hijack via password reset form in Django

relatedVulnerabilities.description: JMSSink in all versions of Log4j 1.x is vulnerable to deserialization of untrusted data when the attacker has write access to the Log4j configuration or if the configuration references an LDAP service the attacker has access to. The attacker can provide a TopicConnectionFactoryBindingName configuration causing JMSSink to perform JNDI requests that result in remote code execution in a similar fashion to CVE-2021-4104. Note this issue only affects Log4j 1.x when specifically configured to use JMSSink, which is not the default. Apache Log4j 1.2 reached end of life in August 2015. Users should upgrade to Log4j 2 as it addresses numerous other issues from the previous versions.

vulnerability.description: Deserialization of Untrusted Data in Log4j 1.x

relatedVulnerabilities.description: Django 1.11.x before 1.11.19, 2.0.x before 2.0.11, and 2.1.x before 2.1.6 allows Uncontrolled Memory Consumption via a malicious attacker-supplied value to the django.utils.numberformat.format() function.

Misconfigurations.Description: When using a 'FROM' statement you should use a specific tag to avoid uncontrolled behavior when the image is updated.
Misconfigurations.Message: Specify a tag in the 'FROM' statement for image 'juliantotzek/verademo1-tomcat'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add a tag to the image in the 'FROM' statement

Misconfigurations.Description: Running containers with 'root' user can lead to a container escape situation. It is a best practice to run containers as non-root users, which can be done by adding a 'USER' statement to the Dockerfile.
Misconfigurations.Message: Specify at least 1 USER command in Dockerfile with non-root user as argument
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'USER <non root user name>' line to the Dockerfile
Misconfigurations.Title: Image user should not be 'root'

Misconfigurations.Description: When using a 'FROM' statement you should use a specific tag to avoid uncontrolled behavior when the image is updated.

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add a tag to the image in the 'FROM' statement

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'USER <non root user name>' line to the Dockerfile

Misconfigurations.Description: Use WORKDIR instead of proliferating instructions like 'RUN cd … && do-something', which are hard to read, troubleshoot, and maintain.
Misconfigurations.Message: RUN should not be used to change directory: 'cd / && tar xzvf /apache-log4j-2.0.1-bin.tar.gz'. Use 'WORKDIR' statement instead.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use WORKDIR to change directory

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'USER <non root user name>' line to the Dockerfile

Misconfigurations.Description: Running containers with 'root' user can lead to a container escape situation. It is a best practice to run containers as non-root users, which can be done by adding a 'USER' statement to the Dockerfile.
Misconfigurations.Message: Specify at least 1 USER command in Dockerfile with non-root user as argument
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'USER <non root user name>' line to the Dockerfile

Misconfigurations.Description: A program inside the container can elevate its own privileges and run as root, which might give the program control over the container and node.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation' to false
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'set containers[].securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation' to 'false'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Process can elevate its own privileges

Misconfigurations.Description: The container should drop all default capabilities and add only those that are needed for its execution.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should add 'ALL' to 'securityContext.capabilities.drop'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'ALL' to containers[].securityContext.capabilities.drop.
Misconfigurations.Title: Default capabilities not dropped

Misconfigurations.Description: Mounting docker.sock from the host can give the container full root access to the host.
Misconfigurations.Message: Pod 'hello' should not specify '/var/run/docker.socker' in 'spec.template.volumes.hostPath.path'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Do not specify /var/run/docker.socket in 'spec.template.volumes.hostPath.path'.
Misconfigurations.Title: hostPath volume mounted with docker.sock

Misconfigurations.Description: Sharing the host’s IPC namespace allows container processes to communicate with processes on the host.
Misconfigurations.Message: Pod 'hello' should not set 'spec.template.spec.hostIPC' to true
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Do not set 'spec.template.spec.hostIPC' to true.
Misconfigurations.Title: Access to host IPC namespace

Misconfigurations.Description: Enforcing CPU limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'resources.limits.cpu'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a limit value under 'containers[].resources.limits.cpu'.
Misconfigurations.Title: CPU not limited

Misconfigurations.Description: 'runAsNonRoot' forces the running image to run as a non-root user to ensure least privileges.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'securityContext.runAsNonRoot' to true
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsNonRoot' to true.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs as root user

Misconfigurations.Description: It is best to avoid using the ':latest' image tag when deploying containers in production. Doing so makes it hard to track which version of the image is running, and hard to roll back the version.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should specify an image tag
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use a specific container image tag that is not 'latest'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Image tag ':latest' used

Misconfigurations.Description: An immutable root file system prevents applications from writing to their local disk. This can limit intrusions, as attackers will not be able to tamper with the file system or write foreign executables to disk.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'securityContext.readOnlyRootFilesystem' to true
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Change 'containers[].securityContext.readOnlyRootFilesystem' to 'true'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Root file system is not read-only

Misconfigurations.Description: When containers have resource requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'resources.requests.cpu'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].resources.requests.cpu'.
Misconfigurations.Title: CPU requests not specified

Misconfigurations.Description: When containers have memory requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'resources.requests.memory'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].resources.requests.memory'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Memory requests not specified

Misconfigurations.Description: Enforcing memory limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'resources.limits.memory'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a limit value under 'containers[].resources.limits.memory'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Memory not limited

Misconfigurations.Description: Force the container to run with user ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'securityContext.runAsUser' > 10000
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsUser' to an integer > 10000.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs with low user ID

Misconfigurations.Description: Force the container to run with group ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'hello' of Pod 'hello' should set 'securityContext.runAsGroup' > 10000
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsGroup' to an integer > 10000.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs with low group ID

Misconfigurations.Description: HostPath volumes must be forbidden.
Misconfigurations.Message: Pod 'hello' should not set 'spec.template.volumes.hostPath'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Do not set 'spec.volumes[*].hostPath'.
Misconfigurations.Title: hostPath volumes mounted

Misconfigurations.Description: Setting a custom SELinux user or role option should be forbidden.
Misconfigurations.Message: Pod 'hello' uses invalid seLinux type 'custom'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Do not set 'spec.securityContext.seLinuxOptions', spec.containers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions and spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seLinuxOptions.
Misconfigurations.Title: SELinux custom options set

Misconfigurations.Description: The RuntimeDefault/Localhost seccomp profile must be required, or allow specific additional profiles.
Misconfigurations.Message: Either Pod or Container should set 'securityContext.seccompProfile.type' to 'RuntimeDefault'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'spec.securityContext.seccompProfile.type', 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile' and 'spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile' to 'RuntimeDefault' or undefined.
Misconfigurations.Title: Default Seccomp profile not set

Misconfigurations.Description: Containers must drop ALL capabilities, and are only permitted to add back the NET_BIND_SERVICE capability.
Misconfigurations.Message: container should drop all
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.drop' to 'ALL' and only add 'NET_BIND_SERVICE' to 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Container capabilities must only include NET_BIND_SERVICE

Misconfigurations.Description: IMDS v2 (Instance Metadata Service) introduced session authentication tokens which improve security when talking to IMDS. By default aws_instance resource sets IMDS session auth tokens to be optional. To fully protect IMDS you need to enable session tokens by using metadata_options block and its http_tokens variable set to required.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance does not require IMDS access to require a token
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable HTTP token requirement for IMDS
Misconfigurations.Title: aws_instance should activate session tokens for Instance Metadata Service.

Misconfigurations.Description: EC2 instance data is used to pass start up information into the EC2 instance. This userdata must not contain access key credentials. Instead use an IAM Instance Profile assigned to the instance to grant access to other AWS Services.

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Remove sensitive data from the EC2 instance user-data
Misconfigurations.Title: User data for EC2 instances must not contain sensitive AWS keys

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should block public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By blocking, PUTs with fail if the object has any public ACL a.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not blocking public acls
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable blocking any PUT calls with a public ACL specified
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should block public ACL

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 bucket policy should have block public policy to prevent users from putting a policy that enable public access.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not blocking public policies
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Prevent policies that allow public access being PUT
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should block public policy

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 Buckets should be encrypted to protect the data that is stored within them if access is compromised.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have encryption enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Configure bucket encryption
Misconfigurations.Title: Unencrypted S3 bucket.

Misconfigurations.Description: Buckets should have logging enabled so that access can be audited.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have logging enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add a logging block to the resource to enable access logging
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Bucket does not have logging enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description:
Versioning in Amazon S3 is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. 
You can use the S3 Versioning feature to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets. 
With versioning you can recover more easily from both unintended user actions and application failures.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have versioning enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable versioning to protect against accidental/malicious removal or modification
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Data should be versioned

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should ignore public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By ignoring rather than blocking, PUT calls with public ACLs will still be applied but the ACL will be ignored.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not ignoring public acls
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable ignoring the application of public ACLs in PUT calls
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access Block should Ignore Public Acl

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should restrict public policies for the bucket. By enabling, the restrict_public_buckets, only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access if it has a public policy.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not restricting public buckets
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Limit the access to public buckets to only the owner or AWS Services (eg; CloudFront)
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should restrict public bucket to limit access

Misconfigurations.Description: The "block public access" settings in S3 override individual policies that apply to a given bucket, meaning that all public access can be controlled in one central types for that bucket. It is therefore good practice to define these settings for each bucket in order to clearly define the public access that can be allowed for it.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have a corresponding public access block.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Define a aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block for the given bucket to control public access policies

Misconfigurations.Description: VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into network traffic that traverses the VPC and can be used to detect anomalous traffic or insight during security workflows.
Misconfigurations.Message: VPC Flow Logs is not enabled for VPC
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable flow logs for VPC

After you've created a flow log, you can view and retrieve its data in Amazon CloudWatch Logs. It is recommended that VPC Flow Logs be enabled for packet "Rejects" for VPCs.

Misconfigurations.Description: There are many scenarios in which you would want to expose a load balancer to the wider internet, but this check exists as a warning to prevent accidental exposure of internal assets. You should ensure that this resource should be exposed publicly.

Misconfigurations.Description:
Amazon ES exposes four Elasticsearch logs through Amazon CloudWatch Logs: error logs, search slow logs, index slow logs, and audit logs. 

Search slow logs, index slow logs, and error logs are useful for troubleshooting performance and stability issues. 

Audit logs track user activity for compliance purposes. 

All the logs are disabled by default.
Misconfigurations.Message: Domain audit logging is not enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable logging for ElasticSearch domains
Misconfigurations.Title: Domain logging should be enabled for Elastic Search domains

Misconfigurations.Description: Traffic flowing between Elasticsearch nodes should be encrypted to ensure sensitive data is kept private.
Misconfigurations.Message: Domain does not have in-transit encryption enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable encrypted node to node communication
Misconfigurations.Title: Elasticsearch domain uses plaintext traffic for node to node communication.

Misconfigurations.Description:
Plain HTTP is unencrypted and human-readable. This means that if a malicious actor was to eavesdrop on your connection, they would be able to see all of your data flowing back and forth.

You should use HTTPS, which is HTTP over an encrypted (TLS) connection, meaning eavesdroppers cannot read your traffic.
Misconfigurations.Message: Domain does not enforce HTTPS.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enforce the use of HTTPS for ElasticSearch
Misconfigurations.Title: Elasticsearch doesn't enforce HTTPS traffic.

Misconfigurations.Description: You should ensure your Elasticsearch data is encrypted at rest to help prevent sensitive information from being read by unauthorised users.
Misconfigurations.Message: Domain does not have at-rest encryption enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable ElasticSearch domain encryption
Misconfigurations.Title: Elasticsearch domain isn't encrypted at rest.

Misconfigurations.Description: You should not use outdated/insecure TLS versions for encryption. You should be using TLS v1.2+.
Misconfigurations.Message: Domain does not have a secure TLS policy.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the most modern TLS/SSL policies available
Misconfigurations.Title: Elasticsearch domain endpoint is using outdated TLS policy.

Misconfigurations.Description: You should use the principle of least privilege when defining your IAM policies. This means you should specify each exact permission required without using wildcards, as this could cause the granting of access to certain undesired actions, resources and principals.

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Specify the exact permissions required, and to which resources they should apply instead of using wildcards.
Misconfigurations.Title: IAM policy should avoid use of wildcards and instead apply the principle of least privilege

Misconfigurations.Description: CIS recommends that you apply IAM policies directly to groups and roles but not users. Assigning privileges at the group or role level reduces the complexity of access management as the number of users grow. Reducing access management complexity might in turn reduce opportunity for a principal to inadvertently receive or retain excessive privileges.
Misconfigurations.Message: One or more policies are attached directly to a user
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Grant policies at the group level instead.
Misconfigurations.Title: IAM policies should not be granted directly to users.

Misconfigurations.Description:
Versioning in Amazon S3 is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. 
You can use the S3 Versioning feature to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your buckets. 
With versioning you can recover more easily from both unintended user actions and application failures.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have versioning enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable versioning to protect against accidental/malicious removal or modification
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Data should be versioned

Misconfigurations.Description: The "block public access" settings in S3 override individual policies that apply to a given bucket, meaning that all public access can be controlled in one central types for that bucket. It is therefore good practice to define these settings for each bucket in order to clearly define the public access that can be allowed for it.

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Define a aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block for the given bucket to control public access policies
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 buckets should each define an aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block

Misconfigurations.Description:
Network ACLs allow you to reduce your exposure to risk by limiting what can access your key vault. 

The default action of the Network ACL should be set to deny for when IPs are not matched. Azure services can be allowed to bypass.
Misconfigurations.Message: Vault network ACL does not block access by default.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a network ACL for the key vault
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault should have the network acl block specified

Misconfigurations.Description:
Expiration Date is an optional Key Vault Key behavior and is not set by default.

Set when the resource will be become inactive.
Misconfigurations.Message: Key should have an expiry date specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set an expiration date on the vault key
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that the expiration date is set on all keys

Misconfigurations.Description:
Content Type is an optional Key Vault Secret behavior and is not enabled by default.

Clients may specify the content type of a secret to assist in interpreting the secret data when it's retrieved. The maximum length of this field is 255 characters. There are no pre-defined values. The suggested usage is as a hint for interpreting the secret data.
Misconfigurations.Message: Secret does not have a content-type specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Provide content type for secrets to aid interpretation on retrieval
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault Secret should have a content type set

Misconfigurations.Description:
Purge protection is an optional Key Vault behavior and is not enabled by default.

Purge protection can only be enabled once soft-delete is enabled. It can be turned on via CLI or PowerShell.
Misconfigurations.Message: Vault does not have purge protection enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable purge protection for key vaults
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault should have purge protection enabled

Misconfigurations.Description:
Expiration Date is an optional Key Vault Secret behavior and is not set by default.

Set when the resource will be become inactive.
Misconfigurations.Message: Secret should have an expiry date specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set an expiry for secrets
Misconfigurations.Title: Key Vault Secret should have an expiration date set

Misconfigurations.Description:
Azure Storage currently supports three versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2. 

Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 on public HTTPS endpoints, but TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.

This check will warn if the minimum TLS is not set to TLS1_2.
Misconfigurations.Message: Storage account uses an insecure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use a more recent TLS/SSL policy for the load balancer
Misconfigurations.Title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2

Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a more restrictive cidr range
Misconfigurations.Title: An inbound network security rule allows traffic from /0.

Misconfigurations.Description:
RDP access can be configured on either the network security group or in the network security group rule.

RDP access should not be permitted from the internet (*, 0.0.0.0, /0, internet, any). Consider using the Azure Bastion Service.
Misconfigurations.Message: Security group rule allows ingress to RDP port from multiple public internet addresses.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Block RDP port from internet
Misconfigurations.Title: RDP access should not be accessible from the Internet, should be blocked on port 3389

Misconfigurations.Description:
Flow logs are the source of truth for all network activity in your cloud environment. 
To enable analysis in security event that was detected late, you need to have the logs available. 
			
Setting an retention policy will help ensure as much information is available for review.
Misconfigurations.Message: Flow log does not enable the log retention policy.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Ensure flow log retention is turned on with an expiry of >90 days
Misconfigurations.Title: Retention policy for flow logs should be enabled and set to greater than 90 days

Misconfigurations.Description:
SSH access can be configured on either the network security group or in the network security group rule. 

SSH access should not be permitted from the internet (*, 0.0.0.0, /0, internet, any)
Misconfigurations.Message: Security group rule allows ingress to SSH port from multiple public internet addresses.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Block port 22 access from the internet
Misconfigurations.Title: SSH access should not be accessible from the Internet, should be blocked on port 22

Misconfigurations.Description:
It is recommended that at least one valid contact is configured for the security center. 
Microsoft will notify the security contact directly in the event of a security incident using email and require alerting to be turned on.
Misconfigurations.Message: Security contact has alert notifications disabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set alert notifications to be on
Misconfigurations.Title: Send notification emails for high severity alerts

Misconfigurations.Description:
To benefit from Azure Defender you should use the Standard subscription tier.
			
			Enabling Azure Defender extends the capabilities of the free mode to workloads running in private and other public clouds, providing unified security management and threat protection across your hybrid cloud workloads.
Misconfigurations.Message: Security center subscription uses the free tier.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable standard subscription tier to benefit from Azure Defender
Misconfigurations.Title: Enable the standard security center subscription tier

Misconfigurations.Description:
It is recommended that at least one valid contact is configured for the security center. 
Microsoft will notify the security contact directly in the event of a security incident and will look to use a telephone number in cases where a prompt response is required.
Misconfigurations.Message: Security contact does not have a phone number listed.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a telephone number for security center contact
Misconfigurations.Title: The required contact details should be set for security center

Misconfigurations.Description: SQL Server sends alerts for threat detection via email, if there are no email addresses set then mitigation will be delayed.
Misconfigurations.Message: Security alert policy does not include any email addresses for notification.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Provide at least one email address for threat alerts
Misconfigurations.Title: At least one email address is set for threat alerts

Misconfigurations.Description: Postgresql can generate logs for successful connections to improve visibility for audit and configuration issue resolution.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server is not configured to log connections.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable connection logging
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure server parameter 'log_connections' is set to 'ON' for PostgreSQL Database Server

Misconfigurations.Description: SSL connections should be enforced were available to ensure secure transfer and reduce the risk of compromising data in flight.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server does not have enforce SSL.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable SSL enforcement
Misconfigurations.Title: SSL should be enforced on database connections where applicable

Misconfigurations.Description: SSL connections should be enforced were available to ensure secure transfer and reduce the risk of compromising data in flight.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server does not have enforce SSL.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable SSL enforcement
Misconfigurations.Title: SSL should be enforced on database connections where applicable

Misconfigurations.Description: Postgresql can generate logs for connection throttling to improve visibility for audit and configuration issue resolution.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server is not configured to throttle connections.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable connection throttling logging
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure server parameter 'connection_throttling' is set to 'ON' for PostgreSQL Database Server

Misconfigurations.Description: Database resources should not publicly available. You should limit all access to the minimum that is required for your application to function.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server has public network access enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable public access to database when not required
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure databases are not publicly accessible

Misconfigurations.Description: Database resources should not publicly available. You should limit all access to the minimum that is required for your application to function.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server has public network access enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable public access to database when not required
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure databases are not publicly accessible

Misconfigurations.Message: Database server has public network access enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable public access to database when not required
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure databases are not publicly accessible

Misconfigurations.Description: Subscription owners should be notified when there are security alerts. By ensuring the administrators of the account have been notified they can quickly assist in any required remediation
Misconfigurations.Message: Security alert policy does not alert account admins.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable email to subscription owners
Misconfigurations.Title: Security threat alerts go to subcription owners and co-administrators

Misconfigurations.Description: Postgresql can generate logs for checkpoints to improve visibility for audit and configuration issue resolution.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server is not configured to log checkpoints.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable checkpoint logging
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure server parameter 'log_checkpoints' is set to 'ON' for PostgreSQL Database Server

Misconfigurations.Description: You should not use outdated/insecure TLS versions for encryption. You should be using TLS v1.2+.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server does not require a secure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the most modern TLS policies available
Misconfigurations.Title: Databases should have the minimum TLS set for connections

Misconfigurations.Description: You should not use outdated/insecure TLS versions for encryption. You should be using TLS v1.2+.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database server does not require a secure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the most modern TLS policies available
Misconfigurations.Title: Databases should have the minimum TLS set for connections

Misconfigurations.Message: Database server does not require a secure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the most modern TLS policies available
Misconfigurations.Title: Databases should have the minimum TLS set for connections

Misconfigurations.Description: Auditing helps you maintain regulatory compliance, understand database activity, and gain insight into discrepancies and anomalies that could indicate business concerns or suspected security violations.
Misconfigurations.Message: Server does not have an extended audit policy configured.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable auditing on Azure SQL databases
Misconfigurations.Title: Auditing should be enabled on Azure SQL Databases

Misconfigurations.Description: SQL Server can alert for security issues including SQL Injection, vulnerabilities, access anomalies and data exfiltration. Ensure none of these are disabled to benefit from the best protection
Misconfigurations.Message: Server has a security alert policy which disables alerts.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use all provided threat alerts
Misconfigurations.Title: No threat detections are set

Misconfigurations.Description:
Some Microsoft services that interact with storage accounts operate from networks that can't be granted access through network rules. 

To help this type of service work as intended, allow the set of trusted Microsoft services to bypass the network rules
Misconfigurations.Message: Network rules do not allow bypass for Microsoft Services.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Allow Trusted Microsoft Services to bypass
Misconfigurations.Title: Trusted Microsoft Services should have bypass access to Storage accounts

Misconfigurations.Description:
Azure Storage currently supports three versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2. 

Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 on public HTTPS endpoints, but TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.

This check will warn if the minimum TLS is not set to TLS1_2.
Misconfigurations.Message: Storage account uses an insecure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use a more recent TLS/SSL policy for the load balancer
Misconfigurations.Title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2

Misconfigurations.Description: Manage disks should be encrypted at rest. When specifying the encryption_settings block, the enabled attribute should be set to true.
Misconfigurations.Message: Managed disk is not encrypted.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable encryption on managed disks
Misconfigurations.Title: Enable disk encryption on managed disk

Misconfigurations.Description: Temporary files are not logged by default. To log all temporary files, a value of `0` should set in the `log_temp_files` flag - as all files greater in size than the number of bytes set in this flag will be logged.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance has temporary file logging disabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable temporary file logging for all files
Misconfigurations.Title: Temporary file logging should be enabled for all temporary files.

Misconfigurations.Description: In-transit data should be encrypted so that if traffic is intercepted data will not be exposed in plaintext to attackers.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance does not require TLS for all connections.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enforce SSL for all connections
Misconfigurations.Title: SSL connections to a SQL database instance should be enforced.

Misconfigurations.Description: Logging connections provides useful diagnostic data such as session length, which can identify performance issues in an application and potential DoS vectors.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance is not configured to log connections.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable connection logging.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that logging of connections is enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: Database instances should be configured so that they are not available over the public internet, but to internal compute resources which access them.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance is granted a public internet address.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Remove public access from database instances
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that Cloud SQL Database Instances are not publicly exposed

Misconfigurations.Description: Database instances should be configured so that they are not available over the public internet, but to internal compute resources which access them.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance allows access from the public internet.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Remove public access from database instances
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that Cloud SQL Database Instances are not publicly exposed

Misconfigurations.Description: Lock waits are often an indication of poor performance and often an indicator of a potential denial of service vulnerability, therefore occurrences should be logged for analysis.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance is not configured to log lock waits.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable lock wait logging.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that logging of lock waits is enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: Logging disconnections provides useful diagnostic data such as session length, which can identify performance issues in an application and potential DoS vectors.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance is not configured to log disconnections.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable disconnection logging.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that logging of disconnections is enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: Automated backups are not enabled by default. Backups are an easy way to restore data in a corruption or data-loss scenario.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance does not have backups enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable automated backups
Misconfigurations.Title: Enable automated backups to recover from data-loss

Misconfigurations.Description: Logging checkpoints provides useful diagnostic data, which can identify performance issues in an application and potential DoS vectors.
Misconfigurations.Message: Database instance is not configured to log checkpoints.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable checkpoints logging.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that logging of checkpoints is enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: Using 'allAuthenticatedUsers' provides any GCP user - even those outside of your organisation - access to your BigQuery dataset.
Misconfigurations.Message: Dataset grants access to all authenticated GCP users.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Configure access permissions with higher granularity
Misconfigurations.Title: BigQuery datasets should only be accessible within the organisation

Misconfigurations.Description: Using 'allUsers' or 'allAuthenticatedUsers' as members in an IAM member/binding causes data to be exposed outside of the organisation.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket allows public access.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Restrict public access to the bucket.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that Cloud Storage bucket is not anonymously or publicly accessible.

Misconfigurations.Description: When you enable uniform bucket-level access on a bucket, Access Control Lists (ACLs) are disabled, and only bucket-level Identity and Access Management (IAM) permissions grant access to that bucket and the objects it contains. You revoke all access granted by object ACLs and the ability to administrate permissions using bucket ACLs.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket has uniform bucket level access disabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable uniform bucket level access to provide a uniform permissioning system.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that Cloud Storage buckets have uniform bucket-level access enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Using unmanaged keys makes rotation and general management difficult.
Misconfigurations.Message: Storage bucket encryption does not use a customer-managed key.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Encrypt Cloud Storage buckets using customer-managed keys.
Misconfigurations.Title: Cloud Storage buckets should be encrypted with a customer-managed key.

Misconfigurations.Description:
By default, Pods in Kubernetes can operate with capabilities beyond what they require. You should constrain the Pod's capabilities to only those required for that workload.

Kubernetes offers controls for restricting your Pods to execute with only explicitly granted capabilities. 

Pod Security Policy allows you to set smart defaults for your Pods, and enforce controls you want to enable across your fleet. 

The policies you define should be specific to the needs of your application
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster pod security policy is not enforced.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use security policies for pods to restrict permissions to those needed to be effective
Misconfigurations.Title: Pod security policy enforcement not defined.

Misconfigurations.Description: The Compute Engine instance metadata server exposes legacy v0.1 and v1beta1 endpoints, which do not enforce metadata query headers. This is a feature in the v1 APIs that makes it more difficult for a potential attacker to retrieve instance metadata. Unless specifically required, we recommend you disable these legacy APIs. When setting the metadata block, the default value for disable-legacy-endpoints is set to true, they should not be explicitly enabled.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster has legacy metadata endpoints enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable legacy metadata endpoints
Misconfigurations.Title: Legacy metadata endpoints enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: IP aliasing allows the reuse of public IPs internally, removing the need for a NAT gateway.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster has IP aliasing disabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable IP aliasing
Misconfigurations.Title: Clusters should have IP aliasing enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: You should create and use a minimally privileged service account to run your GKE cluster instead of using the Compute Engine default service account.
Misconfigurations.Message: Node pool does not override the default service account.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use limited permissions for service accounts to be effective
Misconfigurations.Title: Checks for service account defined for GKE nodes

Misconfigurations.Description: Labels make it easier to manage assets and differentiate between clusters and environments, allowing the mapping of computational resources to the wider organisational structure.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster does not use GCE resource labels.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set cluster resource labels
Misconfigurations.Title: Clusters should be configured with Labels

Misconfigurations.Description: StackDriver monitoring aggregates logs, events, and metrics from your Kubernetes environment on GKE to help you understand your application's behavior in production.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster does not use the monitoring.googleapis.com/kubernetes StackDriver monitoring service.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable StackDriver monitoring
Misconfigurations.Title: Stackdriver Monitoring should be enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: The GKE control plane is exposed to the public internet by default.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster exposes control plane to the public internet.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use private nodes and master authorised networks to prevent exposure
Misconfigurations.Title: GKE Control Plane should not be publicly accessible

Misconfigurations.Description: GKE supports several OS image types but COS is the recommended OS image to use on cluster nodes for enhanced security
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster is not configuring node pools to use the COS containerd image type by default.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the COS image type
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure Container-Optimized OS (cos) is used for Kubernetes Engine Clusters Node image

Misconfigurations.Description: GKE supports several OS image types but COS is the recommended OS image to use on cluster nodes for enhanced security
Misconfigurations.Message: Node pool is not using the COS containerd image type.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the COS image type
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure Container-Optimized OS (cos) is used for Kubernetes Engine Clusters Node image

Misconfigurations.Description: Enabling a network policy allows the segregation of network traffic by namespace
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster does not have a network policy enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable network policy
Misconfigurations.Title: Network Policy should be enabled on GKE clusters

Misconfigurations.Description: If the workload_metadata_config block within node_config is included, the node_metadata attribute should be configured securely. The attribute should be set to SECURE to use metadata concealment, or GKE_METADATA_SERVER if workload identity is enabled. This ensures that the VM metadata is not unnecessarily exposed to pods.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster exposes node metadata of pools by default.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set node metadata to SECURE or GKE_METADATA_SERVER
Misconfigurations.Title: Node metadata value disables metadata concealment.

Misconfigurations.Description: If the workload_metadata_config block within node_config is included, the node_metadata attribute should be configured securely. The attribute should be set to SECURE to use metadata concealment, or GKE_METADATA_SERVER if workload identity is enabled. This ensures that the VM metadata is not unnecessarily exposed to pods.
Misconfigurations.Message: Node pool exposes node metadata.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set node metadata to SECURE or GKE_METADATA_SERVER
Misconfigurations.Title: Node metadata value disables metadata concealment.

Misconfigurations.Description: Automatic updates keep nodes updated with the latest cluster master version.
Misconfigurations.Message: Node pool does not have auto-upgraade enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable automatic upgrades
Misconfigurations.Title: Kubernetes should have 'Automatic upgrade' enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Enabling private nodes on a cluster ensures the nodes are only available internally as they will only be assigned internal addresses.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster does not have private nodes.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable private cluster
Misconfigurations.Title: Clusters should be set to private

Misconfigurations.Description: StackDriver logging provides a useful interface to all of stdout/stderr for each container and should be enabled for moitoring, debugging, etc.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster does not use the logging.googleapis.com/kubernetes StackDriver logging service.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable StackDriver logging
Misconfigurations.Title: Stackdriver Logging should be enabled

Misconfigurations.Description:
You should disable Attribute-Based Access Control (ABAC), and instead use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) in GKE.

RBAC has significant security advantages and is now stable in Kubernetes, so it’s time to disable ABAC.
Misconfigurations.Message: Cluster has legacy ABAC enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Switch to using RBAC permissions
Misconfigurations.Title: Legacy ABAC permissions are enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: Automatic repair will monitor nodes and attempt repair when a node fails multiple subsequent health checks
Misconfigurations.Message: Node pool does not have auto-repair enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable automatic repair
Misconfigurations.Title: Kubernetes should have 'Automatic repair' enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Use of project-wide SSH keys means that a compromise of any one of these key pairs can result in all instances being compromised. It is recommended to use instance-level keys.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance allows use of project-level SSH keys.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable project-wide SSH keys
Misconfigurations.Title: Disable project-wide SSH keys for all instances

Misconfigurations.Description: Instances should not be publicly exposed to the internet
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance has a public IP allocated.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Remove public IP
Misconfigurations.Title: Instances should not have public IP addresses

Misconfigurations.Description: When serial port access is enabled, the access is not governed by network security rules meaning the port can be exposed publicly.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance has serial port enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable serial port access
Misconfigurations.Title: Disable serial port connectivity for all instances

Misconfigurations.Description: Using unmanaged keys makes rotation and general management difficult.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance disk encryption does not use a customer managed key.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use managed keys
Misconfigurations.Title: VM disks should be encrypted with Customer Supplied Encryption Keys

Misconfigurations.Description: Using unmanaged keys makes rotation and general management difficult.
Misconfigurations.Message: Disk is not encrypted with a customer managed key.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use managed keys to encrypt disks.
Misconfigurations.Title: Disks should be encrypted with customer managed encryption keys

Misconfigurations.Description: OS Login automatically revokes the relevant SSH keys when an IAM user has their access revoked.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance has OS Login disabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable OS Login at project level and remove instance-level overrides
Misconfigurations.Title: Instances should not override the project setting for OS Login

Misconfigurations.Description: The virtual TPM provides numerous security measures to your VM.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance does not have VTPM for shielded VMs enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable Shielded VM VTPM
Misconfigurations.Title: Instances should have Shielded VM VTPM enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Disabling IP forwarding ensures the instance can only receive packets addressed to the instance and can only send packets with a source address of the instance.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance has IP forwarding allowed.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Disable IP forwarding
Misconfigurations.Title: Instances should not have IP forwarding enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Integrity monitoring helps you understand and make decisions about the state of your VM instances.
Misconfigurations.Message: Instance does not have shielded VM integrity monitoring enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable Shielded VM Integrity Monitoring
Misconfigurations.Title: Instances should have Shielded VM integrity monitoring enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Network security rules should not use very broad subnets. Where possible, segments should be broken into smaller subnets and avoid using the /0 subnet.
Misconfigurations.Message: Firewall rule allows ingress traffic from multiple addresses on the public internet.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a more restrictive cidr range
Misconfigurations.Title: An inbound firewall rule allows traffic from /0.

Misconfigurations.Description: VPC flow logs record information about all traffic, which is a vital tool in reviewing anomalous traffic.
Misconfigurations.Message: Subnetwork does not have VPC flow logs enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable VPC flow logs
Misconfigurations.Title: VPC flow logs should be enabled for all subnetworks

Misconfigurations.Description:
Network ACLs allow you to reduce your exposure to risk by limiting what can access your key vault. 

The default action of the Network ACL should be set to deny for when IPs are not matched. Azure services can be allowed to bypass.
Misconfigurations.Message: Vault network ACL does not block access by default.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a network ACL for the key vault
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault should have the network acl block specified

Misconfigurations.Description:
Expiration Date is an optional Key Vault Key behavior and is not set by default.

Set when the resource will be become inactive.
Misconfigurations.Message: Key should have an expiry date specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set an expiration date on the vault key
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure that the expiration date is set on all keys

Misconfigurations.Description:
Content Type is an optional Key Vault Secret behavior and is not enabled by default.

Clients may specify the content type of a secret to assist in interpreting the secret data when it's retrieved. The maximum length of this field is 255 characters. There are no pre-defined values. The suggested usage is as a hint for interpreting the secret data.
Misconfigurations.Message: Secret does not have a content-type specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Provide content type for secrets to aid interpretation on retrieval
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault Secret should have a content type set

Misconfigurations.Description:
Purge protection is an optional Key Vault behavior and is not enabled by default.

Purge protection can only be enabled once soft-delete is enabled. It can be turned on via CLI or PowerShell.
Misconfigurations.Message: Vault does not have purge protection enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable purge protection for key vaults
Misconfigurations.Title: Key vault should have purge protection enabled

Misconfigurations.Description:
Expiration Date is an optional Key Vault Secret behavior and is not set by default.

Set when the resource will be become inactive.
Misconfigurations.Message: Secret should have an expiry date specified.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set an expiry for secrets
Misconfigurations.Title: Key Vault Secret should have an expiration date set

Misconfigurations.Description:
You can configure your storage account to accept requests from secure connections only by setting the Secure transfer required property for the storage account. 

When you require secure transfer, any requests originating from an insecure connection are rejected. 

Microsoft recommends that you always require secure transfer for all of your storage accounts.
Misconfigurations.Message: Account does not enforce HTTPS.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Only allow secure connection for transferring data into storage accounts
Misconfigurations.Title: Storage accounts should be configured to only accept transfers that are over secure connections

Misconfigurations.Description:
Azure Storage currently supports three versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2. 

Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 on public HTTPS endpoints, but TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.

This check will warn if the minimum TLS is not set to TLS1_2.
Misconfigurations.Message: Storage account uses an insecure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use a more recent TLS/SSL policy for the load balancer
Misconfigurations.Title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2

Misconfigurations.Message: Security alert policy does not alert account admins.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable email to subscription owners
Misconfigurations.Title: Security threat alerts go to subcription owners and co-administrators

Misconfigurations.Description:
Flow logs are the source of truth for all network activity in your cloud environment. 
To enable analysis in security event that was detected late, you need to have the logs available. 
			
Setting an retention policy will help ensure as much information is available for review.
Misconfigurations.Message: Flow log has a log retention policy of less than 90 days.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Ensure flow log retention is turned on with an expiry of >90 days
Misconfigurations.Title: Retention policy for flow logs should be enabled and set to greater than 90 days

Misconfigurations.Description:
You can configure your storage account to accept requests from secure connections only by setting the Secure transfer required property for the storage account. 

When you require secure transfer, any requests originating from an insecure connection are rejected. 

Microsoft recommends that you always require secure transfer for all of your storage accounts.
Misconfigurations.Message: Account does not enforce HTTPS.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Only allow secure connection for transferring data into storage accounts
Misconfigurations.Title: Storage accounts should be configured to only accept transfers that are over secure connections

Misconfigurations.Description:
Azure Storage currently supports three versions of the TLS protocol: 1.0, 1.1, and 1.2. 

Azure Storage uses TLS 1.2 on public HTTPS endpoints, but TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1 are still supported for backward compatibility.

This check will warn if the minimum TLS is not set to TLS1_2.
Misconfigurations.Message: Storage account uses an insecure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use a more recent TLS/SSL policy for the load balancer
Misconfigurations.Title: The minimum TLS version for Storage Accounts should be TLS1_2

Misconfigurations.Description: The TLS mutual authentication technique in enterprise environments ensures the authenticity of clients to the server. If incoming client certificates are enabled only an authenticated client with valid certificates can access the app.
Misconfigurations.Message: App service does not have client certificates enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable incoming certificates for clients
Misconfigurations.Title: Web App accepts incoming client certificate

Misconfigurations.Description: Registering the identity used by an App with AD allows it to interact with other services without using username and password
Misconfigurations.Message: App service does not have an identity type.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Register the app identity with AD
Misconfigurations.Title: Web App has registration with AD enabled

Misconfigurations.Description: Enabling authentication ensures that all communications in the application are authenticated. The auth_settings block needs to be filled out with the appropriate auth backend settings
Misconfigurations.Message: App service does not have authentication enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable authentication to prevent anonymous request being accepted
Misconfigurations.Title: App Service authentication is activated

Misconfigurations.Description: By default, clients can connect to function endpoints by using both HTTP or HTTPS. You should redirect HTTP to HTTPs because HTTPS uses the SSL/TLS protocol to provide a secure connection, which is both encrypted and authenticated.
Misconfigurations.Message: Function app does not have HTTPS enforced.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: You can redirect all HTTP requests to the HTTPS port.
Misconfigurations.Title: Ensure the Function App can only be accessed via HTTPS. The default is false.

Misconfigurations.Description: Use the latest version of HTTP to ensure you are benefiting from security fixes
Misconfigurations.Message: App service does not have HTTP/2 enabled.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Use the latest version of HTTP
Misconfigurations.Title: Web App uses the latest HTTP version

Misconfigurations.Description: Use a more recent TLS/SSL policy for the App Service
Misconfigurations.Message: App service does not require a secure TLS version.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: The TLS version being outdated and has known vulnerabilities
Misconfigurations.Title: Web App uses latest TLS version

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should block public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By blocking, PUTs with fail if the object has any public ACL a.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not blocking public acls
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable blocking any PUT calls with a public ACL specified
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should block public ACL

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 bucket policy should have block public policy to prevent users from putting a policy that enable public access.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not blocking public policies
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Prevent policies that allow public access being PUT
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should block public policy

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 Buckets should be encrypted to protect the data that is stored within them if access is compromised.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have encryption enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Configure bucket encryption
Misconfigurations.Title: Unencrypted S3 bucket.

Misconfigurations.Description: Buckets should have logging enabled so that access can be audited.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have logging enabled
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add a logging block to the resource to enable access logging
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Bucket does not have logging enabled.

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should ignore public ACLs on buckets and any objects they contain. By ignoring rather than blocking, PUT calls with public ACLs will still be applied but the ACL will be ignored.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not ignoring public acls
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable ignoring the application of public ACLs in PUT calls
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access Block should Ignore Public Acl

Misconfigurations.Description: S3 buckets should restrict public policies for the bucket. By enabling, the restrict_public_buckets, only the bucket owner and AWS Services can access if it has a public policy.
Misconfigurations.Message: No public access block so not restricting public buckets
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Limit the access to public buckets to only the owner or AWS Services (eg; CloudFront)
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 Access block should restrict public bucket to limit access

Misconfigurations.Description: The "block public access" settings in S3 override individual policies that apply to a given bucket, meaning that all public access can be controlled in one central types for that bucket. It is therefore good practice to define these settings for each bucket in order to clearly define the public access that can be allowed for it.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not have a corresponding public access block.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Define a aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block for the given bucket to control public access policies
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 buckets should each define an aws_s3_bucket_public_access_block

Misconfigurations.Description: Encryption using AWS keys provides protection for your S3 buckets. To increase control of the encryption and manage factors like rotation use customer managed keys.
Misconfigurations.Message: Bucket does not encrypt data with a customer managed key.
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Enable encryption using customer managed keys
Misconfigurations.Title: S3 encryption should use Customer Managed Keys

Misconfigurations.Description: A program inside the container can elevate its own privileges and run as root, which might give the program control over the container and node.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation' to false
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'set containers[].securityContext.allowPrivilegeEscalation' to 'false'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Process can elevate its own privileges

Misconfigurations.Description: The container should drop all default capabilities and add only those that are needed for its execution.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should add 'ALL' to 'securityContext.capabilities.drop'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Add 'ALL' to containers[].securityContext.capabilities.drop.
Misconfigurations.Title: Default capabilities not dropped

Misconfigurations.Description: Enforcing CPU limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'resources.limits.cpu'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a limit value under 'containers[].resources.limits.cpu'.
Misconfigurations.Title: CPU not limited

Misconfigurations.Description: 'runAsNonRoot' forces the running image to run as a non-root user to ensure least privileges.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'securityContext.runAsNonRoot' to true
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsNonRoot' to true.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs as root user

Misconfigurations.Description: An immutable root file system prevents applications from writing to their local disk. This can limit intrusions, as attackers will not be able to tamper with the file system or write foreign executables to disk.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'securityContext.readOnlyRootFilesystem' to true
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Change 'containers[].securityContext.readOnlyRootFilesystem' to 'true'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Root file system is not read-only

Misconfigurations.Description: When containers have resource requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'resources.requests.cpu'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].resources.requests.cpu'.
Misconfigurations.Title: CPU requests not specified

Misconfigurations.Description: When containers have memory requests specified, the scheduler can make better decisions about which nodes to place pods on, and how to deal with resource contention.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'resources.requests.memory'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].resources.requests.memory'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Memory requests not specified

Misconfigurations.Description: Enforcing memory limits prevents DoS via resource exhaustion.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'resources.limits.memory'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set a limit value under 'containers[].resources.limits.memory'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Memory not limited

Misconfigurations.Description: Force the container to run with user ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'securityContext.runAsUser' > 10000
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsUser' to an integer > 10000.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs with low user ID

Misconfigurations.Description: Force the container to run with group ID > 10000 to avoid conflicts with the host’s user table.
Misconfigurations.Message: Container 'aerospike' of StatefulSet 'aerospike' should set 'securityContext.runAsGroup' > 10000
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'containers[].securityContext.runAsGroup' to an integer > 10000.
Misconfigurations.Title: Runs with low group ID

Misconfigurations.Description: The RuntimeDefault/Localhost seccomp profile must be required, or allow specific additional profiles.
Misconfigurations.Message: Either Pod or Container should set 'securityContext.seccompProfile.type' to 'RuntimeDefault'
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'spec.securityContext.seccompProfile.type', 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile' and 'spec.initContainers[*].securityContext.seccompProfile' to 'RuntimeDefault' or undefined.
Misconfigurations.Title: Default Seccomp profile not set

Misconfigurations.Description: Containers must drop ALL capabilities, and are only permitted to add back the NET_BIND_SERVICE capability.
Misconfigurations.Message: container should drop all
Misconfigurations.Resolution: Set 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.drop' to 'ALL' and only add 'NET_BIND_SERVICE' to 'spec.containers[*].securityContext.capabilities.add'.
Misconfigurations.Title: Container capabilities must only include NET_BIND_SERVICE
